utterances: Mm-hmm.
And that's not what I - and I think many Cuban-Americans feel the same way.
I don't know if your parents are still living, but would they have felt the same way?
Yes.
I believe so.
My father has since passed away, but my mother feels the same way.
She has no intention of returning.
She's part of that early migration.
We immigrated to this country in 1961, but she feels that this is her country now.
Hmm.
And she - it was difficult enough - you know, it was difficult the first time to uproot oneself and leave one's homeland and come to a new society and try to integrate oneself.
And so, why uproot yourself a second time?
This is her country now.
If you'd like to join our conversation, our number is 800-989-8255, 800-989-TALK.
E-mail us talk@npr.org.
We'll begin with Gladys.
Gladys is calling us from Boynton Beach in Florida.
Yes, hello.
Am I on the air?
Yes.
You're on the air, Gladys.
Please go ahead.
Yes, hi.
I came to this country when I was about eight years old and I agree.
You know, my generation - I'm now, you know, in my early 40's - but my generation doesn't feel that desperate in terms of having to go back and - or what's going on politically with Fidel Castro.
Certainly, we grew up with our grandparents and our parents telling us about their life in Cuba and how much better it was for them there.
But I don't think that - my mom right now has Alzheimer's and couldn't tell me.
But I don't think she would be the one that if everything all of a sudden falls apart would go back because she would consider this her country now.
So I think there is a discrepancy between Cubans who came, you know, recently as opposed to those that came at my time - quite some time ago.
Because this is our country now, we don't really feel that much politically inclined to side with the Cubans now in Cuba.
Or, for that matter, be that interested in what's going on with Fidel's state.
Yeah.
Does his illness - Gladys, does his illness really force everybody to think about this again, though?
I think it just puts in the forefront and, you know, like my - I have little kids and they ask me about it.
And sure I would love to one day visit and take them and have them go as a vacation spot type of spot, but not to go back and live there.
Mm hmm.
And I think that most of my generation would probably feel the same.
It would be nice to go back to see - if we were born there - where we were born and what our parents told us.

But not that we have an interest in going back to living there or finding what our parents owned and doing any of that sort of -and I can see how the Cubans there would feel a little bit upset that, you know, when - like the professor was saying when she went to visit her mom's home.
Because they feel - there are some Cubans here who feel they're going to go back and take everything that was taken from them.
But this is their country now.
They've been here for many years, and they have lives and homes here now.
And that wouldn't be fair to the people who stayed there and now have these homes and these farms or, you know, whatever else that they had back home.
Okay, Gladys.
Thanks very much, and we hope you the best for your mom.
Oh, thank you.
Thanks so much.
Bye-bye.
All righty.
I wonder, Maria Cristina Garcia, you were talking about this diversity which you say has always existed in the Cuban-American community.
Elected officials, at least on the congressional level - and there are three Cuban-Americans in Congress now - all hardliners.
How come that diversity isn't reflected in that community?
Well, because my generation - those who came of age in the United States - don't turn out to vote.
I don't think the moderates are exercising their political voice, at least not in the level that they should.
I mean, when you look at the voter turn out rates - those who self-identify as hardliner -they have an 80-90 percent voter turnout.
And so, of course, that's going to make - that's going to drown out all the other voices.
Mm hmm.
Let's get another caller on the line.
This is Elizabeth.
Elizabeth calling us from Portland, Oregon.
Hi.
I just wanted to comment on my sister-in-law's experience.
She met my brother while he was traveling in Cuban.
He's American.
And then she won the lottery to come here, which she did.
They subsequently had a baby.
When she was being raised in Cuba, she had a favorable experience under Castro.
She was taken through college and then ultimately became an actress on Cuban television.
So she has very high opinions of Castro.
And were she given the opportunity to go back - which she will have in a year, because the three years expires in one year - she will go back and probably frequently.
And were it not for my brother, I'm not sure she wouldn't go back and live there permanently.
Mm hmm.
So that's - Professor Garcia - that's a different opinion.
Yes.
I mean, I think you can point to the list of successes in Cuba, and you can also point to a list of failures.
And we can talk until, you know, until we're blue in the face about which list is longer.

But it seems to me that at this moment in time, when a post-Fidel leadership is going to draw on a new generation of Cubans for its expertise - scholars, scientists, doctors, engineers - we should be reaching out to that generation, you know, instead of engaging in these discussions about how good Cuba is or how horrible it is.
I think, you know, it is what it is.
And I think it's important I think for this generation to begin to discuss ways that we can improve relations between both countries.
Elizabeth, thanks very much.
Appreciate it.
You're welcome.
We're talking today with Cuban-Americans about the future of their community and their relations with their homeland.

I'm Neal Conan.
We'll be back after the break.
It's the TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.

This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan in Washington.
We're talking today with Cuban-Americans about how they view their future.
Our guest is Maria Cristina Garcia, a professor of history at Cornell University.
When news came of Fidel Castro's illness two weeks ago, many of those revelers in the streets of Little Havana and other communities in and around Miami were young Cuban-Americans born in the U.S.
News of their family's homeland is important to them, but their views sometimes differ from their parents and their grandparents.
Susan Anasagasti is a staff writer for The Miami Herald.
And she joins us now from the studios of our member station in Miami, WLRN.
Nice to have you on the program today.
Thank you very much.
You yourself are a young Cuban-American.
Tell us, were there people of your generation dancing when this news broke a couple of weeks ago?
Absolutely.
You know, for them it's really, you know, just taking to the streets.
It's some sort of calling.
It's some sort of sense of responsibility to continue representing the beliefs of their grandparents.
It's their way of feeling close to the island despite never having been there.
So, you know, it was interesting to see that a couple of weeks ago.
Uh-huh.
And just what kind of relationship - I'm not sure you can speak for your generation, I'm not sure anybody can - but young Cuban-Americans what kind of relationships do they want to see with Cuba now?
Well, you know, they would definitely - there are different opinions, of course.
But there's one thing that they all agree on.
That until Cuba becomes a democratic nation, the island, you know, will remain a place where civil liberties are routinely trampled.
And that seems to be the general sense.
That seems to be what they express and what they believe.
And they would like to see, of course.
And that they would like to see.
But we were hearing earlier from Professor Garcia that they are less politically motivated than perhaps the older generation.
Would you say that's true?
From NPR News, this is WEEKENDS ON ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Linda Wertheimer.
Guy Raz is away.
While the American Heritage Dictionary says...
I would say yes.
You know, I think that their motivations are maybe based on sort of the conversations that their parents told them around the dinner table each night.
It may be less political and in some ways also less emotional, but they would just like to - for them it's more of seeing this democratic nation.
You know, they've been talking about this for so long that that's just sort of, you know, the waiting continues for them.
The waiting continues.
So it's this sort of - this longing but not necessarily quite as passionate as their parent's maybe.
Absolutely.
For them - I mean, it's still passionate, of course.
And you did see this, you know, sort of them taking to the streets and celebrating, but it's a different kind of passion.

Just from talking to many of the people all, you know, in Westchester and Little Havana, they - for them it's almost, you know, to see their parents sort of breathe a little better or not have to worry so much about the outcome down there.
Mm hmm.
Yeah.
I understand the last of your family members, an uncle, just moved to this country a few weeks ago.
Yes.
That's correct.
With no family left in Cuba anymore, does this still - is this still as important to you as it used to be?
You know, it absolutely is important to me and it would always be.
Hmm.
